Papillary muscles and Chordae tendineae

The papillary muscles are attached to the inferior ventricular wall. These muscles are connected to the AV-valves via tendons called chordae tendineae. The papillary muscles have no active function in opening or closing the AV-valves. When the AV-valves close the papillary muscles contract, thus providing a controlled mechanism of preventing the AV-valves from protruding into the atria during ventricular systole. This mechanism prevents the backflow of blood from the ventricles into the aorta during ventricular systole. Rupture of a papillary muscle or of the chordae tendineae may result in leakage of an AV-valve, allowing the backflow of blood into the atria during ventricular contraction. This leakage, in turn, may result in heart failure.
